Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2012 08:27AM ShaneOak wrote: ncheatum~ I'm sorry you had to find us, but there is a wealth of information here.  Ultimately, you have to decide what you are comfortable with and no one should pressure you.  Not doctors, family or friends.  I would encourage you to search this site for types of reconstruction and options after a mastectomy (single vs. both).  Get as much information as you can.  And don't feel rushed into any quick choice.  This is your body and your health and you deserve time to make a good choice for YOU. For me, once I knew my diagnosis it was a very quick (definately not easy) decision for me to have a BMX.  I have 3 young children and I did not want to have a lifelone struggle with this if I could help it. It has not been easy physically or emotionally and I'm still very early in this process.  I still feel like it was the best choice for me. This is just my experience.  I hope you find support here in whatever you decide. Sending hugs your way!!

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2013 09:41AM ShaneOak wrote: Bella, so sorry that you had to join us here, but you are in good hands.  This is the scariest time of all and you will find a lot of uncertainly, anger and a whole bunch of other emotions that you never thought you'd feel.  I think that's 100% normal.  Ask a lot of questions and consider lots of options before moving forward.  You will be bombarded with the opinon's of others (not in the medical field) on what you should or should not be doing.  Find the people in your life that love and support you and will be by your side through this rollercoaster of a journey.  If it helps at all, I'm only 3 months out from being diagnosed and I am 100% comfortable with my decisions and diagnosis.  Of course, there are some days where this sneaks up on me and catches my emotions off guard, but mostly life has moved on. Keep us posted about your appointments.  We are here with you and you will get through this!! Love and hugs!

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2013 09:24AM ShaneOak wrote: So sorry that you had to join us, but know that you are in great company and we all are here to support you. No one wants to be part of this club but here we are and it can be a great place.  I know this is very scary  and being an oncology nurse you probably know all the different treatments and have seen so much.  You will get through this and your kids will be okay too.  I have 3 kids, who are a bit younger than yours but they were my priority too through this. From the time I had my Mammo and u/s, the biopsy and surgery (I had a BMX too) was about 2 weeks.  After the pathology came back AFTER surgery, the BS and Oncologist said that the type of DCIS was very aggressive  and that had I waited and put it off, my outcome would have been much different.  I would not be comfortable waiting as long as your doctor has your surgery date (but that's just me).  I think a lot can happen in 4 weeks in terms of the IDC spreading.  Although, I am not a doctor.  Good luck to you and I'm sending encouragement your way!

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 07:40AM ShaneOak wrote: First of all, sorry that you have to be here and for what you're going through.  BUT...this is a great place for information and different perspectives from women that have been there. My mother in law has a doctorate in natural health.  During this process (especially in the beginning), I had much unwanted advice on how I just needed to eat more green vegetables and the cancer cells in my ducts would disappear.  She was often condescending and made me feel as if my decisions were not the right ones.  She quoted studies and rattled off the benefits of natural medicine at every chance she got.  I finally had to tell her that I needed SUPPORT right now, not a lecture.  In anger, I also asked her if she were 39 with 3 kids and a BIRAD 5 diagnoses if she would be okay just eating more broccoli and "waiting it out"?? Maybe you could tell your friend that you love her but need her support through this the most.  This is a scary time and the more support you can find the better. We are all here for you and understand. Good luck in whatever you decide.
